datafield.subfield: Models of life: epigenetics, diversity and cycles

This review emphasizes aspects of biology that can be understood through repeated applications of simple causal rules. The selected topics include perspectives on gene regulation, phage lambda development, epigenetics, microbial ecology, as well as model approaches to diversity and to punctuated equilibrium in evolution. Two outstanding features are repeatedly described. One is the minimal number of rules to sustain specific states of complex systems for a long time. The other is the collapse of such states and the subsequent dynamical cycle of situations that restitute the system to a potentially new metastable state.
Center for Models of Life - Niels Bohr Institute - Blegdamsvej 17 - 2100 Copenhagen - Denmark

When infecting an E. coli, the phage first decides whether to avoid vegetative growth and integrate its genome into that of the host cell (lysogeny), or whether to kill its host and produce about 100 progeny phages (lysis is shown on the right side of figure, 3: #ropaa5aebf03). The frequency of lysogeny choice depends on the conditions, but typically occurs in 1\to 20% of the infection events

When choosing lysogeny, the phage subsequently maintains this lysogenic state in a way that renders it immune to further infections from other lambda phages and is, in fact, able to stay in the host genome as long as any of the components required for maintenance do not mutate. Because these components are encoded in a small fraction of the λ DNA, the maintenance is much more robust than even the genome sequence

Finally the phage is able to escape the bacteria, when the bacteria are exposed to DNA damage, through activation of the so-called SOS pathway. To survive, the released phages subsequently need to find a new host within a few days
Select a random population and replace it with a population of size \gamma \ll 1/N

Immediately after this collapse the freed-up resources lead to the transient exponential growth of all remaining si, until carrying capacity is reached. This is done by re-scaling all populations {{s}_{i}}\to {{s}_{i}}\left(\text{new}\right)={{s}_{i}}/\,\underset{j}{{{\sum}^{}}}\,{{s}_{j}}

Life copies on all scales: From DNA, to cells, to individuals, to children that copy the behavior of their parents. This involves enormous computational power and storing capability, as well as a variety of self-correcting mechanisms that act in analogy to molecular-scale proof-reading [, 223: #ropaa5aebbib223]

Biology is the result of a very long historical process as highlighted first by Darwin [, 3: #ropaa5aebbib003]. A process that uses the fact that competition between large complicated organisms favors evolution by tinkering rather than the invention of completely new organisms from scratch [, 224: #ropaa5aebbib224]
Self-assembly is inherent for life, and is essential for the production of new cells using information from their ancestors

At the molecular scale, life is made of 1D strings: DNA, RNA, and proteins. This makes it possible to merge the scale of '{{k}_{\text{B}}}T-physics' associated to individual hydrogen bonds with the specificity and precision one needs on the scale of the individual macromolecule

Living organisms, in particular, sense new information. We see, hear, and smell in order to obtain knowledge that allows us to forecast the future and respond appropriately. Inherently, to obtain this new information is to adapt [, 225: #ropaa5aebbib225-, 228: #ropaa5aebbib228]. This makes us sensitive to changes rather than to absolute conditions

Negative feedback is an essential component of life. This allows biological organisms to optimize their protein composition to the need defined by the current environment [, 2: #ropaa5aebbib002,, 92: #ropaa5aebbib092]

Positive feedback is important for life and decision-making. Genetic switches and self-amplification serve to make living systems decisive and thereby able to be in discrete specialized states. The combination of positive and negative feedback allows signal propagation, as in excitable media (electric-pulse propagation in neurons, or in our hearts [, 229: #ropaa5aebbib229], or signaling molecules in early development [, 230: #ropaa5aebbib230])

Specialization and high diversity is the norm. From proteins each performing their tasks in the cell, and cells performing a wide variety of functions in the body, to animal species that create niches for each other by each doing what they are best at
An aspect of specialization is extensive transport. It is often needed or practical to separate production and usage, making transport coupled to the diversity of tools, abilities and opportunities

Counteracting forces or the ongoing activity of opposing modifications are found from folded versus open states of proteins, and ultra-sensitive signal propagation [, 231: #ropaa5aebbib231], to maintenance of epigenetic states of cells, and predator-prey relations in food webs

Stochastic processes are observed from the Brownian motion and fluctuations at the single-molecule level, to the discrete nature of gene expression events, and the life and death of individuals as well as entire species. Life easily provides amplification mechanisms that act from the emergence of single-point mutations to changes of whole ecosystems (e.g. through emergent diseases)

Ubiquitous cycles, instead of back and forth motions. The conversion of energy to ATP or ATP to work involves a cyclic change of states: 1\to 2\to 3\to 1\to 2\to 3\to 1\to.... where at least one of the transitions demands external input. On a larger scale we also saw cyclic transitions of temperate phages between entry, maintenance and exit. We saw how cycles of invasions in microbial ecosystems can prevent development of a universally fit phage (figure, 12: #ropaa5aebf12), and how cycles of invading non-motile species can play a crucial role in generating a diverse and rich system from an otherwise coarsening system (see figure, 22: #ropaa5aebf22)
